words.latinSentence: Canis Rufus cum puero in horto ludit.
words.englishSentence: The dog Rufus plays with the boy in the garden.

words.latinSentence: Coquus Marcus cenam parat in culina.
words.englishSentence: The cook Marcus prepares dinner in the kitchen.
Marcus is a diligent student.

words.latinSentence: Pater spectat fīlium in horto ludere.
words.englishSentence: The father watches his son playing in the garden.
The mother gathers roses in the garden.
The girl walks in the old street.
The slave works diligently in the house.

words.latinSentence: Māter curam habet de familia sua.
words.englishSentence: The mother takes care of her family.
The father always gives advice.

words.latinSentence: Senex sedet sub arbore in horto.
words.englishSentence: The old man sits under the tree in the garden.
The slave cleans the house before dinner.

words.latinSentence: Discipuli ambulant in via ad scholam.
words.englishSentence: The students walk in the street to school.
The loyal friend is always present.
The maid tidies the house with care.
The family gathers together for dinner.
Delicious food appears on the table.
The master rules the house with dignity.

words.latinSentence: Puer dormit post longam diem ludendi.
words.englishSentence: The boy sleeps after a long day of playing.

words.latinSentence: Servus intrat in atrium cum celeritate.
words.englishSentence: The slave enters the atrium quickly.
The happy girl smiles in the garden.

words.latinSentence: Magister laudat discipulos pro eorum labore.
words.englishSentence: The teacher praises the students for their work.

words.latinSentence: Mercātor diligenter mercem vendit in foro.
words.englishSentence: The merchant diligently sells his goods in the market.
Marcus also comes to dinner.
The maid greets her friends with joy.
The girl walks to the market.
The boy drinks water after playing.
The student looks around in the new classroom.

words.latinSentence: Puer clāmat cum laetitia in via.
words.englishSentence: The boy shouts with joy in the street.
Look! The dog runs through the market.

words.latinSentence: Marcus et Lucius in ludum eunt.
words.englishSentence: Marcus and Lucius go to play.

words.latinSentence: Puella exit ex domo ad ludum.
words.englishSentence: The girl goes out of the house to play.

words.latinSentence: Magister īrātus est de tardis discipulis.
words.englishSentence: The teacher is angry about the late students.
The slave carries food to the table.

words.latinSentence: Discipulus respondet ad magistrum cum respectu.
words.englishSentence: The student replies to the teacher with respect.

words.latinSentence: Puella rīdet in schola cum amicis.
words.englishSentence: The girl laughs with her friends at school.

words.latinSentence: Salvē! in via pueri inter se vocant.
words.englishSentence: Hello! the boys call to each other in the street.
The boy gets up early for school.

words.latinSentence: Mercator in taberna novas res ostendit.
words.englishSentence: The merchant shows new items in the shop.
The maid sees the city from the window.
The master drinks wine at the banquet.
